Faculty Tenure
The subject of faculty tenure has been and still is a
controversial issue on many college campuses. Last Spring
the Johns Hopkins chapter of the American ;Association
of University Professors passed a resolution urging the
University administration to extend tenure to the associate
professorship level.
Tenure is the term used, by way of explanation,
for the right of a professor to hold his job, immune from
arbitrary dismissal. A faculty member holding tenure can
he dismissed from his position only after fair hearing at
which legitimate reasons for the termination of his professorship are put forth by the administration or department head.
Up to this point tenure extends only to full professors
here at Johns Hopkins. Most universities have by now
granted this important benefit to associate professors also.
This would certainly be a wise step for the Hopkins
administration to take. A scholar, having attained the position of associate professor, has established himself with the
University and community. An assistant professor demonstrates his ability and reliability and is promoted to an
associate position with added pay and prestige as inducement to remain at the university. He deserves the security
of tenure if he is expected to settle in the community, raise
his family, and base his life around his university position.
Although this gives the departmental chairman somewhat less flexibility in handling his department, it will
improve the calibre of the men he attracts and the conditions they work under. This University has been fortunate in not haying as yet any bitter conflicts resulting in
the summary dismissal of a faculty member. However,
should such a case arise it would be for the benefit of all
concerned to hale a written tenure clause.

on the whole done little or nothing to even express, their

in the surrounding community, and to a limited extent
;within the university structure itself.
Are the conditions in Baltimore vastly different from
those in Towson? We believe not. The university must
realize its responsibility to its students, visitors, the community, the nation, and indeed to the ideal of liberal

Faculty Tenure
The subject of faculty tenure has been and still is a
controversial issue on many college campuses. Last Spring
the Johns Hopkins chapter of the American ;Association
of University Professors passed a resolution urging the
University administration to extend tenure to the associate
professorship level.
Tenure is the term used, by way of explanation,
for the right of a professor to hold his job, immune from
arbitrary dismissal. A faculty member holding tenure can
he dismissed from his position only after fair hearing at
which legitimate reasons for the termination of his professorship are put forth by the administration or department head.
Up to this point tenure extends only to full professors
here at Johns Hopkins. Most universities have by now
granted this important benefit to associate professors also.
This would certainly be a wise step for the Hopkins
administration to take. A scholar, having attained the position of associate professor, has established himself with the
University and community. An assistant professor demonstrates his ability and reliability and is promoted to an
associate position with added pay and prestige as inducement to remain at the university. He deserves the security
of tenure if he is expected to settle in the community, raise
his family, and base his life around his university position.
Although this gives the departmental chairman somewhat less flexibility in handling his department, it will
improve the calibre of the men he attracts and the conditions they work under. This University has been fortunate in not haying as yet any bitter conflicts resulting in
the summary dismissal of a faculty member. However,
should such a case arise it would be for the benefit of all
concerned to hale a written tenure clause.
